results.title: Dissection of the heart (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Autopsy Dissection Technique”.
Shows the dissection and removal of the heart from the pericardial sac. Demonstrates in detail the opening of the various chambers, the dissection of the coronary arteries, and the examination of the various valves and their measurement. Concludes with the method of cutting and examining the myocardium.

results.title: Dispute
results.creator_credit: Basic Films, Leon Clore and Fred Moore
results.brief_description: A study of a typical industrial dispute and the real reason behind it. A personal incident between an operative and a foreman grows, until the whole factory is brought to a stand-still. Concentrates in turn on the operative, the foreman, the shop steward and the factory manager, showing how each of them came to take the attitude he did and how each felt he had no alternative and was unable to withdraw.

results.title: Disney Masterclass with Roy Conli and Glen Keane [excerpt]
results.brief_description: Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. In this masterclass, as part of the Disney : Dreams Come True exhibition at ACMI, Keane discusses the innate ability for children to express emotion through drawing and the inspiration for the character ‘Ariel’ in ‘The Little Mermaid’.

results.title: Disney Masterclass with Roy Conli and Glen Keane
results.brief_description:
Disney Animator Glen Keane and Producer Roy Conli presented a special Masterclass sharing their behind-the-scenes insights and love of the animation process.
Glen Keane has been with the Walt Disney Studios for over 25 years and is best known for his character animations for feature films such as ‘The Little Mermaid’, ‘Aladdin’, ‘Beauty and the Beast’, ‘Tarzan’, and ‘Tangled’. He reflects on the inspirations for some of his characters and expressing yourself through drawing.
Roy Conli is the producer of the Disney feature animated film, ‘Tangled’, based on the story of Rapunzel. He explains the role of the producer and the line between creating a safe and fertile environment for artists and getting a film made on time and within budget.

results.title: Disney's very merry Christmas songs
results.brief_description: Join your favourite Disney characters in these traditional Christmas songs including “Deck the Halls”, “Jingle Bells”, “Joy to the World”, “Let it Snow!”, “Sleigh Ride”, “Parade of the Wooden Soldiers”, “Winter Wonderland”, “Here Comes Santa Claus”, “Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer”, “Silent Night” and “We Wish You a Merry Christmas”. The words of the carols appear on screen so you can sing along.

results.title: Disney's haunted Halloween
results.brief_description: Goofy learns from an animated Jack O’Lantern that Halloween is a great time to find out about old time holiday traditions and superstitions. Looks at why people dress in costumes and how “trick” or “treating” started. The program also contains appropriate warnings about cautious behaviour during such a festive time.

results.title: Disney's best: the fabulous '50s
results.brief_description: Walt Disney and his staff of animators the 1950s were marked by transitions and experimentation, resulting in some of the most revolutionary cartoons ever released. The technique of “limited animation” and sylised design won “Toot, whistle, plunk and boom” the Academy Award for Best Cartoon Short Subject of 1953. Breakthrough results were also achieved in “Noah’s Ark”, which utilised stop-action photography and the animation of stick figures composed on pencils, cork and pipe cleaners. Titles included are: “Lambert, the sheepish lion” 1951, “Pigs is pigs” 1954, “Toot, whistle, plunk and boom” 1953, and “Noah’s Ark” 1959.

results.title: Disney's Aladdin
results.brief_description: Based on the film of the same name, Disney’s Aladdin is a 2D side-scrolling video game in which the player characters are Aladdin and his monkey Abu.
results.description: Disney’s Aladdin is a 1993 video game developed by Capcom for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES). Based on the film of the same name, Disney’s Aladdin is a 2D side-scrolling video game in which the player characters are Aladdin and his monkey Abu. The game was released in November 1993, the same month that another game with the same title was released by Virgin Games for Sega Genesis. The two games vary in several respects, including the fact that Aladdin carries a sword in the Virgin game but does not in the Capcom game, a fact that Shinji Mikami, the Capcom game’s designer, said made the Virgin game better. The Capcom game was ported to Game Boy Advance (GBA) on March 19, 2004.
description_for_label: Disney’s Aladdin is a 1993 video game developed by Capcom for the Super Nintendo Entertainment System (SNES). The game was released in November 1993, the same month that another game with the same title was released by Virgin Games for Sega Genesis. The two games vary in several respects, including the fact that Aladdin carries a sword in the Virgin game but does not in the Capcom game, a fact that Shinji Mikami, the Capcom game’s designer, said made the Virgin game better. The Capcom game was ported to Game Boy Advance (GBA) on March 19, 2004.
